reviewText:
Boy, I wish I loved anything as much as this game loves crashing. There's not even any rhyme or reason as to WHY it could be crashing sometimes; it's just doing it because it has a burning passion for crashing and it's not going to let you or its parents or the town mayor tell it otherwise. It crashes at the start menu. It crashes at the loading screens. It crashes if you try and record it. It crashes when you enter a room. Let me tell you, if Case #8 could crash while it was crashing, it'd be all over that. There are people kept in padded cells and fed on a pole that are more stable than this game.

Which is kind of a shame because, honestly, Case #8 isn't a horrible game. 'Good' might be stretching it but it's at least average, bundles together a handful of decent scares and is fairly priced. From what I managed to play, there's nothing in the way of combat with the game wheeling out some basic puzzles and item collecting instead as you progress around the prison, gathering the odd piece of scattered lore here and there. It's pasted together in FPS Creator which might well be the source of its problems as this definitely isn't the first time a game from there has been spat out riddled with mystifying bugs.

Obviously, I can't recommend something this ridiculously broken at the moment, regardless of the game's quality. It's possible to shoulder your way through a lot of the crashes by reloading or relaunching but I reached a point after the third stage where it refused to pass the loading screen five times in a row and, with the gaming backlog I'm sure we all share, I had to ask myself whether it was worth the strife to persist with it. I settled on a 'no'.

Whatever joy I managed to squeeze out of this crashaholic is below:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7l1PWCaeW3M

reviewText:
Game crashed a few minutes in. Maybe it'll be fixed in the future.
No explanation of controls leading to lots of guessing.
No clear explanation (or indication) if a door is locked or needs power or is unlocked.

You're a prisoner in an underground prisoner put in isolation. You were sent to prison for murdering your family. I guess you are innocent? You are told all this in some fairly clunky text.

Level design looks okay from what little I saw before the crash.

I'd wait on this one folks. Maybe the developers will fix it and make it a bit more stable.

reviewText:
4.8/10 - Almost a Winner, Just A Little Too Raw!

I don't know if this is considered the finished product; but I can say that there is definitely room for improvement. My computer sucks, but its old school consistent and never has programs crash. This game with amazing accuracy will crash every 15-30 minutes for no apparent reason.

You are prisoner #8, and have allegedly killed (7) other people including your family. Something at the underground prison has gone ghastly wrong and an opportunity to escape has presented itself. You attempt to flea but soon realize things aren't going to be as easy as anticipated. You are not alone…

Overall, the game is pretty average once you get past the crashes. Everything is just a little too bare bones for me to completely enjoy this one. There are no settings, no characters, little story elements and too few interactive elements. If anything I would classify this as an Early Access Exploration game.

Worth $0.99-$1.99 assuming you know up front about the issues.

reviewText:
Case #8 is yet another cookie-cutter first person horror game.  I'd say it's a technically poor one, but despite the frequent crashes and bugs, it does get an acceptable framerate, so overall it's average for its genre in that area.

Walk around a bunch of poorly lit rooms, pick up items and activate arbitrary event flags so that you can open doors and walk around more poorly lit rooms.  If that sounds boring as hell, don't worry.  The game also attempts a few jump scares, which lack any followup and thus end up being about as scary as a typical YouTube Poop.

The story is a different kind of bad in each chapter.  Chapter 1 sets up the bland escape the place" plot common among amateur games.  In chapter 2 you have to glitch yourself through a door to get some dynamyte
date: which you then stand too close to as it goes off in order to set up the next chapter.  Chapter 3 is a clone of P.T.  I haven't played or even watched P.T.
recommended: but I can still tell it's a clone because the level's Steam Trading Card is labeled "P.T."  I guess when you admit your game is a rip-off it instantly becomes an homage.  Finally
hoursPlayed: chapter 4 reveals that the player character committed the crime that the game said he committed at the beginning
voteText: and then ends with a "To be continued."  So in summary
helpfulPercent: the game goes from cliché storm to idiot plot to borderline plagiarism and concludes on an anticlimax.  What a great way to spend an hour and a half.\n\nIt's okay for the game to suck
votesFunny: and everyone knows that MSRP is the only metric on which we should base our expectations.  Nevermind that good games like Ballpoint Universe: Infinite are in the same price point; if it's under five bucks

reviewText:
Unplayably broken.
At first I wasn't able to run the game at all. After giving the program admin privileges it finally started, showing me immediately the main menu. There's no logo, no title screen, nothing. Weird. And in the menu I've discovered the game doesn't allow you to change anything - not even screen resolution or mouse sensitivity.  That is absolutely unacceptable.
The game itself looks surprisingly nice for a low-budget title and the puzzles in the first level were quite entertaining. However, the game keeps crashing, for example when accessing the video terminal. This is pretty bad because it doesn't save your position in the middle of the level so the crash means you have to start over from the beginning.
And then I reached the elevator, the game saved... and crashed again. And since then the loaded position crashed every single time, preventing me from ever seeing level 2.
It's a shame because the game looked promising. Right now I'm asking for a refund but if the game gets fixed, let me know and I may update the review.

reviewText:
IntroductionCase #8 is a horror adventure game that makes you play as a character in a deep underground prision. The game involves some puzzles to complete in order to progress, I feel like this game has a lot of potential but for the time being it still has it's crashes here and there whlist your playing through the game.

GameplayWhen you think of a typical horror game you might think of complicated puzzles that make the game string along a bit more and make your playtime on that game a bit more than you would of liked. Although, Case #8 has very simple and easy puzzles that you can get through fairly quickly. The hardest part about the game would be finding the correct equipment in the game in order to finish a puzzle. Even then though, thanks to the graphics it kind of stands out what you can interact with and where the tools could possibly be. This really helps the game as it does not try to make you have a longer playtime on the game from the difficult puzzles that are in most horror games. But would you would expect in a horror game would be, well, scares throughout the game to keep you on edge. But, unfortunatly there really aren't any scares at all which lets the game down slightly. There are no jumpscares, which are the most cheap and common, nothing that will really make you terrified or keep you on edge. There is no tutorial for the game to tell you what each of the controls are, maybe even a screen at the beginning of the game with the controls would've been nice. It's not exactly hard to figure out how to move and interact with objects and stuff.

For the graphics that are in this game, there's nothing that really seems to be good or to be a very high quality. Some of the walls look a bit bad, and since the game basically uses the same walls over and over you will have ti put up with it throught the game. The lighting of the game seems to be well done, as most of the lights are very dim which is what you would expect from a horror game. This really creates a nice atmospheric feel that there isn't any power through this prison and that there is obviously something out there to get you like in most horror games.

On the other hand, the sound effects of this game are very good. Each of the sound effects are very well designed, such as the doors opening when you unlock them and your footsteps when you are obviously walking. All the sounds that are produced are of a very high quality, and definatly makes you feel as if you are in the game and such.

Pros+ Very atmospheric
+ Nice sounds effects
+ The lighting is very nice
+ Good price
+ Trading Cards

Cons- The graphics are a bit off for the quality
- There are no scares

Result / Final thoughtsCase #8 isn't much of a scary game, which is a little disappointing for such a horror game that really sets up a tense atmosphere. The lighting is very nice, really seems like there is hardly any power to the areas, and the sound effects of the game are reallly good quality that also sets the atmosphere. For the price that the game is asking for, it's a nice horror game, just not many scares throughout the game to keep you on the edge.

Rating: 7.5/10

For more reviews on a wide range of games, go and follow Sometimes You Playing curator group here.

reviewText:
I rarely ever give a negative review but when I do it's for a good reason. I played your game today for about 40minutes or so and I sadly had to stop playing it and you'll see once my video that I made of your game goes up tomorrow at 4pm on my youtube channel.

I'll start of by saying I had mixed feelings about the game. I liked it in someways and disliked it in other ways.

Positives :
1. Good Scares
2. Good ambiance noises
3. Nice graphics

Negatives:
1. Game crashes after every loading screen.
2.There are some glitches in the game where my character cant move.
3. I was confused about the laser guns and why nothing was happenig when all of the beams were on? I was wandering for a good 15minutes or so trying to figure out what I was missing and couldnt find anything.
4. The character's slow paced walk is too slow for my liking, even pressing the shift button down doesn't make the character go that much quicker.

I didn't want a bad experience on this game. infact I was very much extied to try this out and have a good outcome..sadly this didn't happen. I can only be honest with my opinions from the experience I've had. I think personally the game needs more work and the glitche's and crashing needs to be resolved in order for people to have a better experience.

If the crashing and the glitches get resolved then yes, I maycome back to this and try again. However, while the game has these issues I cannot recommend it at all.

reviewText:
Video Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yogEQQyOeE0

Graphics: 3/10 - anything other than the wall textures look pretty bad, that is really all that needs to be said about the graphics.

Sound: 8/10 - The sound is very good considering how mediocre the graphics are. There are no moments when I thought that maybe this isn’t the right song for this part, and overall, the sound definitely made the experience better.

Gameplay: 4/10 - This is just a puzzle game with multiple areas to go through. Obviously, most horror games are going to be like this, but most horror games try to lead the player to the scary situations, whereas this one doesn’t.

Atmosphere: 6/10 - The sound really bumped this score up, but also the lighting in the game is phenomenal. It really plays to the idea that there isn’t a lot of power being directed to the prison, so a lot of areas are lit very poorly. Just the combination of the sound and lighting really made it feel scary.

Scares: 1/10 - There really aren’t any scares. Simple as that.

Do I recommend it? Yes. The game is very enjoyable outside of the regular crashes, and for $4, and 1-2 hours of gameplay is pretty decent.

reviewText:
Honestly the game is kind of interesting, but not really worth the price.

The graphics were nice, and the atmosphere was great, but the world still felt blocky, so adding more static objects or something to make it feel real and not square would be awesome. The walking felt really slow, but considering the first part of the game is set in a small area, it makes some sense if they want the game to play a tad longer, but even the running was barely faster than that and felt way too slow for a game. The puzzles I played were pretty bland, lack-luckster, and had been done countless times since the 90's, nothing really special there, although I didn't get the full experience as the game keeps crashing when loading the 2nd area. Sound effects were great, but the lack of music made it awkward. No, not tense, or suspensful. Awkward, and kind of distracting from the whole atmostphere.

The writing seems bland, un-motivated, and very simplistic. It's kind of obvious they were going off of nothing here, which isn't inherently bad, but it really didn't have anything special going for it. Bland puzzles"
